I notice that in the most recent year (only one given) for each of these major sports leagues, those with the largest disparity between the percentage of players of color and leadership of color are the NFL (61% gap), followed by the WNBA (58% gap) and then the NBA (50% gap). Despite progress or initiatives that have been implemented to address the discrepancies seen above, more work needs to be done. Catchy headline? “Commissioners: Mind the Gap!”

original_comment:
I notice that these segmented bar graphs show a significant disparity between the percentage of players of color and head coaches of color in major sports leagues. This is most apparent in the NFL, where 74% of players are POC while only 13% of coaches are—a difference of 61%. The gap is apparent in all five sports shown, which indicates that the phenomenon is not likely to be due to random chance. 
I wonder why the gap in percentages varies across different types of sports. For example, there is only a 20% gap in baseball compared to the 61% gap in football. I also wonder why there is such a large discrepancy between the percentage of players and head coaches of color in the first place. 
This graph makes me reflect on how we seem to be reluctant to have people of color in leadership positions, and how we can do better in the future. In my community, I am reminded that it is essential to uplift and empower people of color to give them equal leadership opportunities. 
This graph shows a clear pattern: the percentage of lead coaches of color is significantly lower than players of color across major sports. A headline could be “Diversity in Team Leadership: Are We Truly Equal?”

original_comment:
As I look at this graph, I notice that in every major league sport, the percentage of players of color is higher than the percentage of head coaches of color. I can’t help but wonder if this is because of the smaller sample size of the head coaches.

In the MLB’s case, there are only 30 managers total, one for each team. Each team has, at most, a 40-player expanded roster. With 30 teams in the league, there can be a maximum of 1,200 players that play for the MLB at once. The difference between the minuscule amount of managers and the much larger number of players makes me wonder how much the sample size comes into play. If each team had a 1:1 manager/player ratio, would the percentage of head coaches of color still only be 20 percent?

The issue of the small sample size also is relevant in each one of the other sports. The NFL has the highest number of head coaches, at 32. The NFL has more than 1,500 active players every year, which gives a much higher opportunity for diversity than the mere 32 coaches. When it comes down to it, I think the reason the percentages of diversity are much lower in coaches is because of availability. The average NFL player’s career only lasts 3.3 seasons, whereas the average NFL head coach’s career is nearly a full year longer, averaging out at 4.3 seasons. To me, the long career, as well as the limited availability, are very large factors in whether or not a position is diverse or not, because the positions are not being filled as quickly.

Group 6: Rose Zwettler, Kate Shepard, Grace Urban, and Alex Scott
“The Coaching Gap: Underrepresentation in Professional Sports”

We noticed that there are a lot more players of color in each group than head coaches of color. This made us wonder why this gap in player and coaching representation exists. We also noticed that soccer and baseball have the lowest percentage of colored players. On the other side of it, Major League Soccer has the highest percentage of head coaches of color. Another thing we noticed was that all of the data is from 2020 except for one group, the Women’s National Basketball Association which is from 2019. This makes you curious as to why they would include data from a different year only for one of the groups. This also made us wonder why they would only show one women's sport out of the 5 sports showcased. Lastly, we noticed that for the MLB, managers were counted as head coaches instead of the actual coaches being counted. This made us wonder why they would have to count managers and not head coaches like they did for every other sport. From our observations and wonderings, we thought of the data’s impact on our community. For one, it makes it clear that to our community that there is a major problem with underrepresented coaches of color in professional sports. From that it makes us question what we as a community can do to lessen this issue.

original_comment: From this graph, I noticed that quite a high percentage of players across several sports are players of color, whereas not many coaches are. This may mean that talent leads to POC landing player roles, but because of systemic racism and other things in society it is harder for POC to climb up in managerial roles and earn higher wages. 1) There is a much higher overall percentage of players of color then there are of head coaches of color. And these variables don’t seem to be directly correlated with one another. Major League Soccer has the second lowest percentage of players of color (60%) but also has the highest percentage of lead coaches of color (41%). So “most diverse league” is a hard title to give. But “least diverse league” is pretty easy.
